content.webTitle: In brief: Funny Ha Ha; Under Occupation; Jog On – review

fields.headline: In brief: Funny Ha Ha; Under Occupation; Jog On – review
fields.bodyText: Funny Ha Ha Paul Merton Head of Zeus, £25, 633pp As you might expect from as singular a comic talent as Paul Merton, this compilation of his favourite funny stories offers material both hilarious and unusual. Alongside Wodehouse and Saki are contemporary writers including Margaret Atwood and Ali Smith, the latter’s bizarre tale of an unusual encounter on a shopping trip being one of the best things here. It’s also hard to beat Kevin Barry’s uproarious Beer Trip to Llandudno – a finely wrought tale of alcohol-fuelled male bonding. Under Occupation Alan Furst Weidenfeld & Nicolson, £20, 206pp One of the characters in Alan Furst’s new novel, a publisher, remarks that his author is “a master of the form” who has produced “an entertainment, but a smart one, written with a sharp eye and a big heart”. This is a fitting description for this second world war thriller, a gripping story of a novelist handed a top-secret blueprint by a dying man and tasked with getting it into the hands of the French resistance while hounded by the Gestapo. Furst’s writing sometimes verges on the perfunctory – a possible consequence of his frantic plotting – but the twists and intrigue keep coming. Jog On Bella Mackie HarperCollins, £8.99, 288pp (paperback) Bella Mackie’s first book, subtitled How Running Saved My Life, is an elegant, uplifting means of discussing her battles with anxiety and depression. Mackie doesn’t sugarcoat the difficulties that led her to start running, or the problems she has faced as a runner – thankfully, this is not a book in which the writer becomes an ultra-marathon winner. In an accessible fashion, Mackie makes the idea of pulling on trainers and pounding the pavements life-affirming. • To order Funny Ha Ha, Under Occupation or Jog On go to guardianbookshop.com. Free UK p&p over £15
